cleanText:
Good afternoon everyone. Uh, welcome to Proof of Talk in Paris. My name is Gareth Jenson. I'm the head of multimedia here at COINTELEGRAPH, and it's a great pleasure to be live streaming from the event. Um, next to me, I've got Jacob Robert Steeves, who's the co-founder of Bittensor. Um, before we get started with our conversation, I just want to invite you, the viewer out there, to drop your questions in the comment section below. Whether you're watching us on X or on YouTube, any questions you want to know about Bittensor, about Tao, now is your chance to ask Jacob. So, please throw your questions in the comments, and uh, we look forward to posing some of those questions towards the end of this 20-minute conversation. And we're going to have to keep it short and sharp because I've got a panel at 2:00 sharp. So, we're going to have a quick 20-minute conversation about Bittensor and uh, a quick overview of proof of talk. Jacob, it's great to meet you. It's great to chat to you in person. Um, let's start off with a philosophical question. Why did you build Bittensor? What does it solve? What does it prove? And uh, yeah, why does the world need this technology, especially when we're seeing AI tools develop as quickly as they are? I think a good way to get into that is with a story. Um, when I was at Google, I was working in AI at Google, and I ended up working for a team that uh, it's called Google Brain. Uh, it's like the highest level, the pinnacle of it's like the brain of Google, you know, and I was I was asked to work on a project, um, and the goal of the project was to generate images that would go into the watermarks, so like behind, not able to be seen of advertisements, to manipulate people's uh, likelihood to click on the ad. Um, and so it's like massive subliminal messaging. Um, gray area, right? It's like, is that legal? Is that not legal? Like, I don't think that our legal structures are even capable of really measuring that. Um, and I I kind of think that that was wrong. Yeah. Um, and you know, these types of problems stem from um, really the structure that you have a technology inside. So, Google as a corporation is a structure, um, where there are clear incentives for how people move and how those people control commodities and how they control compute and how they they follow out their careers and how they make money. Uh, and it makes them ultimately, it makes corporations become um, you know, at first the heroes and then the villains, uh, because they have a fidiciary responsibility, uh, and they need to maximize as much uh, money they can make per quarter, and so you get these types of, I not say nefarious, but like questionable ethical decisions that happen in corporations just as a consequence of like, hey, look, bro, I'm part of a system, and this is how I'm going to feed my kids. Yeah.
It also points to, and and so like that's why I I think it's important that we actually build in the open, right? So, blockchain technology is about decentralization, but it's and decentralization, what does that actually entail? It means that a lot of people can can own some technology. It's sort of like democratically owned. It can, it's permissionless in the sense you can come to own it. Like, it's not something that's like above and beyond you. It's not something that's in a walled garden. You can access, control, run, participate in the system, but also decentralized systems have to be transparent. Mhm.
Like, the the the clear structure of that incentive is is well understood, like a legal structure, like out in the open, right? You can you can investigate the structure of law in a government and see whether or not like that has a is going to have a good outcome for humanity. Not the case with technology.
